revisions.rev:
{{Infobox software | name = LibreOffice | title = LibreOffice | logo = [[File:LibreOfficelogo.svg|220px]] | screenshot = [[File:LibreOffice startcentre.png|300px]] | caption = StartCentre in LibreOffice 3.4.0 | developer = [[The Document Foundation]] | released = {{Start date|2011|1|25|df=yes}}<!-- Initial release is the first stable version of the software. --> | frequently_updated = Yes | programming_language = [[C++]] and [[Java (programming language)|Java]] | operating_system = [[BSD]], [[Linux]], [[Mac OS X]] and [[Microsoft Windows]]<ref name="Sys">{{cite web |title=System Requirements |format=Uses CSS3 |publisher=libreoffice.org |year=2011 |url=http://www.libreoffice.org/get-help/system-requirements/ |accessdate=14 October 2011}}</ref><ref name="lo-download">{{cite web|url=http://www.libreoffice.org/download/ |title=Productivity Suite Download |publisher=LibreOffice |date= |accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref> | platform = [[IA-32]] and [[x64]]<ref name="lo-download" /> | language = 114 languages<ref name="lo-download" /> | genre = [[Office suite]] | license = [[GNU Lesser General Public License|GNU LGPLv3]]<ref name="About">{{cite web|url = http://www.libreoffice.org/about-us/license/ |title=GNU LGPL License |accessdate=7 January 2011|last = [[The Document Foundation]] |year=2007 |month=June}}</ref> | website = {{URL|http://www.libreoffice.org}} }} '''LibreOffice''' (pronounced {{IPA-en|ËliË.brÉËÉ.fÉªs|}}) is a [[free and open source]] [[office suite]] developed by [[The Document Foundation]] as a [[fork (software development)|fork]] of [[OpenOffice.org]]. It is largely compatible with other major office suites, including [[Microsoft Office]], and available on a variety of platforms. Its developers' goal is to produce a vendor-independent office suite with [[ODF]] file support, accessible to anyone and led by developers which do not have to sign their name to the product.
''LibreOffice'' is a [[hybrid word]], meaning "Free Office". ''Libre'' means ''free'' ([[Gratis versus libre|as in freedom]]) in French and Spanish.
LibreOffice has been downloaded approximately 7.5 million times since its first stable launch in January 2011.<ref name="The Register">{{cite web |url= http://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/09/28/libreoffice_celebrates_first_birthday/ |author=Iain Thomson |title=On its first birthday, LibreOffice has reason to celebrate |accessdate=28 September 2011}}</ref> It is the default office suite in many [[Linux distribution]]s, such as [[Fedora (operating system)|Fedora]],<ref>{{cite web |url= http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Features/LibreOffice |accessdate=2 April 2011 |title=Features/LibreOffice |work=fedoraproject.org}}</ref> [[Linux Mint]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.h-online.com/open/news/item/Linux-Mint-11-Katya-released-1250921.html |title=Linux Mint 11 "Katya" released |work=The H |publisher=[[Heinz Heise]] |date=26 May 2011 |accessdate=29 May 2011}}</ref> [[openSUSE]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.opensuse.org/2011/03/07/opensuse-11-4-will-be-first-to-roll-out-with-libreoffice/ |title=openSUSE 11.4 Will Be First To Roll Out With LibreOffice |work=opensuse.org |date=7 March 2011 |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> and [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/features/office-applications |title=Features/Office applications |work=ubuntu.com |accessdate=3 May 2011}}</ref><!--NOTE:
These are examples only. Please don't keep adding more Linux distributions that offer LibreOffice.
-->
LibreOffice can be run on [[Microsoft Windows]] 2000 (with Service Pack 4 or newer) or newer, [[Mac OS X]] 10.4 Tiger or newer, and [[Linux]]-based systems running [[Linux kernel]] version 2.6.18 or newer.<ref name="Sys" /> Ports for [[FreeBSD]] and [[OpenBSD]] are being maintained by contributors to those projects, respectively.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://github.com/bapt/libreoffice-ports |title=bapt/libreoffice-ports - GitHub |author=bapt |date=13 August 2011 |work=libreoffice-ports |publisher=GitHub |accessdate=26 October 2011}}</ref><ref>The [http://openports.se/editors/libreoffice OpenBSD port of LibreOffice] is being [http://blog.documentfoundation.org/2011/01/21/developer-interview-robert-nagy/ maintained by Robert Nagy in collaboration with The Document Foundation].</ref><ref>[http://openbsd.org/49.html#new LibreOffice was ported to OpenBSD in time for the 4.9 release.]</ref>
==History== ===Initial release=== [[File:libreoffice writer .png|thumb|LibreOffice Writer 3.3 running on [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]]]] On 28 September 2010, several members of the [[OpenOffice.org]] project formed a new group called "The Document Foundation". The Document Foundation created LibreOffice from their former project in response to [[Oracle Corporation]]'s purchasing of [[Sun Microsystems]] over concerns that Oracle would either discontinue OpenOffice.org, or place restrictions on it as an open source project, as it had on Sun's [[OpenSolaris]].<ref name="doc foundation announcement">{{cite web |url=http://www.documentfoundation.org/contact/tdf_release.html |title=OpenOffice.org Community announces The Document Foundation |accessdate=9 November 2011 |author=The Document Foundation |date=28 September 2010 |work=documentfoundation.org |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20100930085933/http://www.documentfoundation.org/contact/tdf_release.html |archivedate = 30 September 2010}}</ref><ref name="collins-29-09-10">{{cite web|last=Collins|first=Barry|title=OpenOffice group breaks away from Oracle|url=http://www.pcpro.co.uk/news/361516/openoffice-group-breaks-away-from-oracle|publisher=PC Pro|accessdate=9 November 2011}} </ref><ref name="Clarke-29-09-10">{{cite web|last=Clarke|first=Gavin|title=OpenOffice files Oracle divorce papers|url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2010/09/28/openoffice_independence_from_oracle/|publisher=The Register|accessdate=9 November 2011}}</ref><ref name="Paul-28-09-10">{{cite web|last=Paul|first=Ryan |title=Document Foundation forks OpenOffice.org, liberates it from Oracle|url=http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2010/09/document-foundation-forks-openofficeorg-to-liberate-it-from-oracle.ars|publisher=Ars Technica|accessdate=9 November 2011}}</ref>
It was originally hoped that the LibreOffice name would be provisional, as Oracle was invited to become a member of The Document Foundation. Oracle rejected requests to donate the OpenOffice.org brand to the project<ref>{{cite web |title=OpenOffice.org Community announces The Document Foundation |publisher=[[The Document Foundation]] |date=28 September 2010 |url=http://www.documentfoundation.org/lists/announce/msg00000.html |accessdate=21 October 2010}}</ref> and demanded that all members of the OpenOffice.org Community Council involved with The Document Foundation step down from the OOo Community Council, citing a conflict of interest.<ref name="ArsTechnica1010">{{cite web|last=Paul|first=Ryan|title=Oracle wants LibreOffice members to leave OOo council |url= http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2010/10/oracle-wants-libreoffice-members-to-leave-ooo-council.ars |work=Ars Technica|accessdate=23 February 2011}}</ref>
The [[Go-oo]] project was discontinued in favour of LibreOffice.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://go-oo.org/|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6344C4AJM|archivedate=9 November 2011|accessdate=9 November 2011|title=Your Office Suite|publisher=Go-oo}}</ref> Improvements made by the project were merged into LibreOffice. Enhancements made in other forks are also expected to be incorporated into LibreOffice.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Document Foundation FAQ |publisher=[[The Document Foundation]] |date=28 September 2010 |url=http://www.documentfoundation.org/faq/ |accessdate=5 October 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Edge |first=Jake |title=Michael Meeks talks about LibreOffice and the Document Foundation |work=[[Linux Weekly News]] |publisher=Eklektix |date=28 September 2010 |url=http://lwn.net/Articles/407339/ |accessdate=28 July 2011}}</ref> Also underway is the reduction of Java dependency,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://listarchives.documentfoundation.org/www/announce/msg00016.html |title=[tdf-announce] TDF offers preview of future product and technology developments - The Document Foundation Mailing List Archives |publisher=listarchives.documentfoundation.org |accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref> with the goal of minimizing security issues and improving application stability.{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}}
As a result of the fork of OpenOffice.org into LibreOffice, and the resulting loss of developers, Oracle announced in April 2011 that it was terminating the commercial development of OpenOffice.org.<ref name="ARS18Apr11">{{Cite news|url=http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2011/04/oracle-gives-up-on-ooo-after-community-forks-the-project.ars|title=Oracle gives up on OpenOffice after community forks the project |accessdate=19 April 2011|last=Paul|first=Ryan|year=2011|month=April|work=[[Ars Technica]]}}</ref> In June 2011, Oracle announced<ref>{{cite press release|title=Statements on OpenOffice.org Contribution to Apache|publisher=Oracle Corporation|date=1 June 2011|url=http://www.marketwire.com/press-release/statements-on-openofficeorg-contribution-to-apache-nasdaq-orcl-1521400.htm|accessdate=14 October 2011}}</ref> that it would contribute the OpenOffice.org code and trademark to the [[Apache Software Foundation]], which decided to accept the offer and start an incubation process within the foundation.
[[Google]] and [[Red Hat]] began to contribute programmers to LibreOffice in June 2011.<ref>{{cite news|last=Noyes|first=Katherine|title=Google Throws Its Weight Behind LibreOffice|work=Linux Line|publisher=[[PC World]]|date=20 June 2011|url=http://www.pcworld.com/businesscenter/article/230728/google_throws_its_weight_behind_libreoffice.html|accessdate=14 October 2011}}</ref>
===Version 3.3=== [[File:LibreOffice Impress 3.3.png|thumb|Impress in LibreOffice 3.3.0]] [[Image:LibreOffice Calc 3.3.png|thumb|right|Screenshot of LibreOffice Calc 3.3]] LibreOffice 3.3.0 Beta 1, which was based on the beta release of OpenOffice.org 3.3, was made available on 28 September 2010âthe day "The Document Foundation" was announced to act as the suite's public figurehead. The first stable version of 3.3 was released on 25 January 2011.<ref>{{cite web|author=Name (required) |url=http://blog.documentfoundation.org/2011/01/25/the-document-foundation-launches-libreoffice-3-3/ |title=The Document Foundation launches LibreOffice 3.3 |publisher=Blog.documentfoundation.org |date=25 January 2011 |accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref> Because The Document Foundation and most of the software's new and former developers considered LibreOffice a direct continuation of OpenOffice.org, LibreOffice 3.3 continued the OpenOffice.org version numbering.
LibreOffice 3.3 features several functions not found in its OpenOffice.org counterpart, mainly as a result of Oracle's strict policies on tracking copyright ownership. Most of the features found in the 3.3 release were directly adapted from several already-created plugins, as well as the Go-oo fork. Among features unique to LibreOffice are:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.libreoffice.org/download/new-features-and-fixes/ |title=New Features |publisher=LibreOffice |date= |accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref> * [[Scalable Vector Graphics|SVG]] image import * [[IBM Lotus Word Pro|Lotus Word Pro]] and [[Microsoft Works]] import filters * Improved [[WordPerfect]] import * Dialog box for title pages * Navigator lets one heading be unfolded as usual in a tree view. * "Experimental" mode that allows unfinished features to be tried by users * Some bundled extensions, including Presenter View in Impress * Colour-coded document icons * On Linux, the [[GStreamer]] multimedia framework is used to render multimedia content such as videos.
===Version 3.4=== [[File:LO34movecopysheet.png|thumb|upright|Redesigned Move/Copy Sheet dialog in Calc]] [[File:LOImprovegtkThemeIntegration.png|thumb|Improved GTK+ theme integration]] The second major release of LibreOffice is version 3.4, first released on 3 June 2011.<ref name="releaseplan"/><ref name="RelAnn34">{{cite web |url= http://blog.documentfoundation.org/2011/06/03/the-document-foundation-announces-libreoffice-3-4-0/ |title=The Document Foundation Announces LibreOffice 3.4.0 |accessdate=3 June 2011 |last=[[The Document Foundation]] |year=2011 |month=June}}</ref> Early versions of v3.4 contained some bugs, including compatibility issues with Microsoft Office, and was therefore only recommended as suitable for early adopters.<ref name="v340releasenote">{{cite web |url=http://www.libreoffice.org/download/release-notes/#LO340|title=Release Notes Â» LibreOffice |accessdate=19 June 2011}}</ref> By 3.4.2, the release was considered suitable for enterprises.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://blog.documentfoundation.org/2011/08/01/libreoffice-3-4-2-for-enterprise-users/ |title=LibreOffice 3.4.2 for enterprise users |accessdate=2 August 2011 |last=[[The Document Foundation]] |year=2011 |month=August}}</ref>
New features and improvements in 3.4 include:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiki.documentfoundation.org/ReleaseNotes/3.4 |title=Release Notes 3.4 |publisher=Wiki.documentfoundation.org |date=19 August 2011 |accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref> * Memory usage improvements<ref name="libre-3.3">{{cite web |url=http://www.developer.com/open/libreoffice-3.3-frees-open-source-office-suite.html |title=LibreOffice 3.3 Frees Open Source Office Suite |work=developer.com |accessdate=25 March 2011}}</ref> * Improvements to Calc, including improved speed and improved compatibility with Microsoft Excel, including [[pivot table]]s (formerly called DataPilot in OOo/LO), support for an unlimited number of fields, and a redesigned Move/Copy Sheet dialog<ref name="RelAnn34" /><ref name="LibreOffice34"/> * There is now no need to close Writer's style edit dialog to check how a new style looks.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://vmiklos.hu/blog/lo-apply |title=Apply button to style edit dialog in Writer |author=Miklos Vajna |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref> * Several thousand lines of German comments were translated into English and over 5,000 lines of [[dead code]] were removed from Writer, Calc and Impress.<ref name="RelAnn34" /> * Improved [[GTK+]] theme integration<ref name="RelAnn34" /> * The Linux version renders fonts via [[cairo (graphics)|Cairo]] so that text in LibreOffice is rendered the same as the rest of the desktop.<ref name="LibreOffice34">{{cite web|url=http://www.libreoffice.org/download/3-4-new-features-and-fixes/ |title=LibreOffice 3.4 New Features and Fixes |publisher=Libreoffice.org |date= |accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref> * Reduction of LibreOffice's reliance on Java<ref name="libre-3.3" /> * Continuing the transition to [[Make (software)|GNU Make]] for building LibreOffice<ref>Meeks, Michael [http://people.gnome.org/~michael/blog/2011-05-09-libreoffice-fud.html LibreOffice is the future of Free Software Office suites]</ref>
===Release schedule=== [[File:Libreoffice-versions.png|thumb|Table showing the release cadence]] The Document Foundation intends to release new major versions of LibreOffice once every six months and to eventually align with the March/September schedule of the other major free software projects.<ref name="releaseplan">{{cite web | url=http://wiki.documentfoundation.org/ReleasePlan | title=Release Plan | work=The Document Foundation Wiki | accessdate=25 March 2011 }}</ref>
The Foundation provides two different versions of LibreOffice. The latest version is available for users looking for the latest enhancements while the previous version caters to users who prefer stability.<ref>{{cite web |author=italovignoli |title=LibreOffice 3.4.1 provides stable new features for every user |work=The Document Foundation Blog |publisher=[[The Document Foundation]] |date=1 July 2011 |url= http://blog.documentfoundation.org/2011/07/01/libreoffice-3-4-1-provides-stable-new-features-for-every-user/ |accessdate=14 October 2011}}</ref>
==Features== ===Included applications===
{| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | Component !! Description |- | [[File:LibreOffice Writer icon 3.3.1 48 px.svg]] | '''[[LibreOffice Writer|Writer]]''' | A [[word processor]] with similar functionality and file support to [[Microsoft Word]] or [[WordPerfect]]. It also can act as a basic [[WYSIWYG]] editor.<ref name="LOFeatures" /> |- | [[File:LibreOffice Calc icon 3.3.1 48 px.svg]] | '''[[LibreOffice Calc|Calc]]''' | A [[spreadsheet]] program, similar to [[Microsoft Excel]] or [[Lotus 1-2-3]]. It has a number of unique features, including a system which automatically defines series of graphs, based on information available to the user.<ref name="LOFeatures" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.libreoffice.org/features/calc/ |title=LibreOffice Calc |publisher=Libreoffice.org |date= |accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref> LibreOffice Calc still has a function called "Solver" but it is slightly different to that in OpenOffice.org.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} |- | [[File:LibreOffice Impress icon 3.3.1 48 px.svg]] | ''' Impress''' | A [[presentation program]] resembling [[Microsoft Powerpoint]]. Presentations can be exported as [[SWF]] files, allowing them to be viewed on any computer with Adobe Flash installed.<ref name="LOFeatures" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.libreoffice.org/features/impress/ |title=LibreOffice Impress |publisher=Libreoffice.org |date= |accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref> LibreOffice Impress also includes 3D transition effects.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} |- | [[File:LibreOffice Base icon 3.3.1 48 px.svg]] | '''Base''' | A [[database management program]], similar to [[Microsoft Access]]. LibreOffice Base allows the creation and management of databases, preparation of forms and reports that provide end users easy access to data. Like Access, it can be used as a front-end for various database systems, including Access databases ([[Microsoft Jet Database Engine|JET]]), [[ODBC]] data sources, and [[MySQL]] or [[PostgreSQL]].<ref name="LOFeatures" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.libreoffice.org/features/base/ |title=LibreOffice Base |publisher=Libreoffice.org |date= |accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref> |- | [[File:LibreOffice Draw icon 3.3.1 48 px.svg]] | '''Draw''' | A [[vector graphics editor]] and diagramming tool similar to [[Microsoft Visio]] and comparable in features to early versions of [[CorelDRAW]]. It provides connectors between shapes, which are available in a range of line styles and facilitate building drawings such as [[flowchart]]s. It also includes features similar to desktop publishing software such as [[Scribus]] and [[Microsoft Publisher]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.libreoffice.org/features/draw/ |title=LibreOffice Draw |publisher=Libreoffice.org |date= |accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref> |- | [[File:LibreOffice Math icon 3.3.1 48 px.svg]] | '''Math''' | An application designed for creating and editing mathematical formulae. The application uses a variant of [[XML]] for creating formulas, as defined in the OpenDocument specification. These formulas can be incorporated into other documents in the LibreOffice suite, such as those created by Writer or Calc, by embedding the formulas into the document.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.libreoffice.org/features/math/ |title=LibreOffice Math |publisher=Libreoffice.org |date= |accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref> |}
LibreOffice also includes a PDF creator and a PDF import tool.
===Supported formats=== LibreOffice can import and export documents in several [[file format]]s;<ref name="LOFeatures">{{cite web|url = http://www.libreoffice.org/features/|title = Features|accessdate =28 March 2011|last = [[The Document Foundation]]|authorlink = |year = undated}}</ref> its native format is the [[OpenDocument Format]] (ODF). Formats supported (for reading and writing) include those used by Microsoft Office, including the [[Office Open XML]] specification used in Microsoft Office 2007 and 2010, which use the .docx, .pptx and .xlsx extensions, as well as to the older file formats used in Microsoft Office 95 and 97-2003, which use .doc, .ppt and .xls extensions. It also supports [[Rich Text Format|Rich Text File format (.rtf)]] and [[OpenOffice.org XML]] format.<ref name="XMLformats">{{cite web|url=http://help.libreoffice.org/Common/XML_File_Formats |title=Common/XML File Formats - LibreOffice Help |publisher=Help.libreoffice.org |date= |accessdate=18 November 2011}}</ref> LibreOffice can save password-protected [[Microsoft Excel|XLS]] files. It uses only one basic encryption method compatible with many spreadsheet applications (for example [[Gnumeric]]).{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}}
LibreOffice has [[Visual Basic for Applications|VBA]] macro support. It can import files from [[MS Works]] and [[Lotus Word Pro]]. [[LibreOffice Draw]] has native functionality to open [[Scalable Vector Graphics|SVG]] files, whereas [[OpenOffice.org]] Draw requires an extension.<ref name="svg">[http://wiki.services.openoffice.org/wiki/SVG_Import_Filter SVG Import Filter] - OpenOffice.org wiki</ref><ref>[http://extensions.services.openoffice.org/project/svgimport SVG Import Extension] - OpenOffice.org repository for extensions</ref><ref>[http://extensions.services.openoffice.org/project/SVGTiny2OO SVG Tiny Import/Export] (does not work with OOo 3.1) - OpenOffice.org repository for extensions</ref> There is improved [[Windows Metafile|EMF]] drawing and [[WordPerfect]] Graphics import.
Exporting to a number of non-editable formats is supported. All documents can be exported to the [[PDF]] format,<ref name="LOFeatures" /> as well as presentations to [[Adobe Flash]] (SWF).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.libreoffice.org/features/impress/ |title=Impress Features |publisher=LibreOffice |date= |accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref> LibreOffice also has the ability to import documents in read-only mode in the [[Uniform Office Format]],<ref name="OpenOffice and LibreOffice share the same source code and data formats">{{cite web|url=http://wiki.services.openoffice.org/wiki/Documentation/OOo3_User_Guides/Getting_Started/File_formats |title=File formats - Apache OpenOffice.org Wiki |publisher=Wiki.services.openoffice.org |date= |accessdate=18 November 2011}}</ref> [[Data Interchange Format]]<ref name="OpenOffice and LibreOffice share the same source code and data formats" /> and the formats of Microsoft Works,<ref name="OpenOffice and LibreOffice share the same source code and data formats" /> WordPerfect,<ref name="OpenOffice and LibreOffice share the same source code and data formats" /> Lotus 1-2-3.<ref name="OpenOffice and LibreOffice share the same source code and data formats" />
===Common features=== Unlike OpenOffice.org, LibreOffice uses the [[GStreamer]] multimedia framework in Linux to render multimedia content such as videos in Impress and other programs. Visually, LibreOffice uses the large "[[Tango Desktop Project|Tango]] style" icons that are used for the application shortcuts, quick launch icons, icons for associated files and for the icons found on the toolbar of the LibreOffice programs.<ref name="tango">{{cite web|url=http://tango.freedesktop.org/Tango_Showroom#OpenOffice.org |title=Tango style OpenOffice.org |publisher=Tango.freedesktop.org |date=12 September 2008 |accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref><ref name="ooo3">{{cite web|url=http://ui.openoffice.org/nonav/VisualDesign/OOo30MimeType.html |title=OpenOffice.org 3.0 icons |publisher=Ui.openoffice.org |date= |accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref> They are also used on the toolbars and menus by default. OpenOffice.org uses small icon sizes and the "Classic" or "Galaxy" icon style by default.<ref name="tango">{{cite web|url=http://www.gnomejournal.org/article/52/dancing-tango-on-the-desktop |title=Dancing Tango on the desktop |publisher=GNOME Journal |date=22 February 1999 |accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref><ref name="icons">[http://www.oooninja.com/2008/04/galaxy-icon-set-theme-look.html OpenOffice.org icon sets]</ref><ref name="icons-evolution">{{cite web|url=http://ui.openoffice.org/VisualDesign/OOo_icon_evolution.html |title=Evolution of toolbar icons |publisher=Ui.openoffice.org |date=29 January 2009 |accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref> LibreOffice also ships with a modified theme which looks native on GTK based Linux distributions. It also renders fonts via [[cairo (graphics)|Cairo]] on Linux distributions; this means that text in LibreOffice is rendered the same as the rest of the Linux desktop.<ref name="LibreOffice34"/> The first run wizard from OpenOffice.org that guides a user through the setting of user name and the registration process has been removed from LibreOffice.<ref name="wizard">{{cite web|url=http://wiki.services.openoffice.org/wiki/Documentation/Administration_Guide/Deactivating_Registration_Wizard |title=OpenOffice.org first start wizard |publisher=Wiki.services.openoffice.org |date= |accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref>
===Future Developments=== In 2011, it was announced that plans are under way to port LibreOffice to both [[Android (operating system)|Android]] and [[iOS]].<ref name="ars technia">{{cite web |url= http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2011/10/libreoffice-gaining-momentum-heading-to-android-ios-and-the-web.ars |author=Ryan Paul |title=LibreOffice gaining momentum, heading to Android, iOS, and the Web |accessdate=17 October 2011}}</ref>
LibreOffice Online will allow for the use of LibreOffice through a simple web browser by using the [[canvas element]]. Development is ongoing and it has not yet been released.<ref name="ars technia" />
==Users== As of September 2011, The Document Foundation estimates that there are 10 million users worldwide who have obtained LibreOffice via downloads or CDs. Over 90% of those are on Windows, with another 5% on Mac OS X. There are an estimated 15 million Linux users, with most having obtained the software directly from their distribution. This gives a total estimated user base of 25 million people.<ref name="1st ann">{{cite web | url=http://blog.documentfoundation.org/2011/09/28/the-document-foundation-celebrates-its-first-anniversary/ | title=The Document Foundation celebrates its first anniversary | work=The Document Foundation Blog | accessdate=28 September 2011 }}</ref>
In 2011, the administrative authority of [[Ãle-de-France (region)|Ãle-de-France]] (which includes the city of [[Paris]]) has decided to include LibreOffice in a [[USB key]] given to students which contains free open source software. The USB key is given to approximately 800,000 students.<ref name="ars technia"/>
The Document Foundation has set a target of 200 million users worldwide before the end of the decade.<ref name="1st ann"/>
